title: Updating and Expanding a Retro-digitised Dictionary: Some Insights from the Dictionary of the Irish Language
segmentation: The Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language or E.

Bill, as it's better known, is a freely available and well used online resource equipped with a variety of advanced search functions and presented within what aims to be at least an intuitive and user friendly front end website.

Covering the language from the earliest evidence up till about the year 1650, the dictionary is a standard reference point for scholars of the Irish language, but the current website has been optimized for use on mobile devices in the hope of better serving the student population.

A succession of different general editors and researchers, and a rush into print to meet the demands of use it or lose it funding, which resulted in a particularly problematic first volume and about of negative criticism.
After the second volume had been published, it was decided to continue on to the revised title of contributions to a Dictionary of the Irish language in a bid to expedite the project.
But the time work wrapped up in the 1970s, more than 43,000 headwords have been generated, generated, and hundreds of thousands of citations listed in evidence.

In the early years of the 21st century, Professor Greg Toner on a team from the University of Ulster took on the work of digitising.
